coredata.dc:title: Hollow cubic Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 dual Z-scheme heterojunctions with wide-spectrum response and enhanced photothermal and photocatalytic-fenton performance

coredata.dc:description: The assembly photocatalyst with rational design of nanostructure can effectually inhibit the rapid charge recombination and improve the photocatalytic performance. Herein, a hollow cubic Cu2-xS/Fe-polyoxometalate/AgVO3 (Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3) dual Z-scheme heterojunction superstructure is constructed on the surface of a hollow cubic Cu2-xS with a clear structure by continuous growth deposition. The hollow cube structure can promote the utilization of light through the refraction and reflection of light in the cavity. Fe-POMs act as the linker between Cu2-xS and AgVO3, providing adequate active sites. In addition, due to the surface plasmon resonance effect of Cu2-xS, Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 has an obvious photothermal effect, which extends the photoresponse to near-infrared region. The hollow cubic Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 photocatalyst has excellent photocatalytic-Fenton degradation rate of 98.6 % for bisphenol A within 150 min due to the formation of dual Z-scheme heterostructures benefiting spatial charge separation. This work provides new insights for fabricating superstructure photocatalyst with high-performance and broad-spectrum response.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The assembly photocatalyst with rational design of nanostructure can effectually inhibit the rapid charge recombination and improve the photocatalytic performance. Herein, a hollow cubic Cu2-xS/Fe-polyoxometalate/AgVO3 (Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3) dual Z-scheme heterojunction superstructure is constructed on the surface of a hollow cubic Cu2-xS with a clear structure by continuous growth deposition. The hollow cube structure can promote the utilization of light through the refraction and reflection of light in the cavity. Fe-POMs act as the linker between Cu2-xS and AgVO3, providing adequate active sites. In addition, due to the surface plasmon resonance effect of Cu2-xS, Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 has an obvious photothermal effect, which extends the photoresponse to near-infrared region. The hollow cubic Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 photocatalyst has excellent photocatalytic-Fenton degradation rate of 98.6 % for bisphenol A within 150 min due to the formation of dual Z-scheme heterostructures benefiting spatial charge separation. This work provides new insights for fabricating superstructure photocatalyst with high-performance and broad-spectrum response.

ce:section.ce:para: Solar-driven photocatalysis has been widely concerned in solving energy and environmental problems due to its avirulence, mild reaction conditions, and sustainability [1â4]. For decades, zero-dimensional (0D) quantum dots (QDs) have attracted wide attention in the field of photocatalysis due to their small sizes, short effective charge transfer lengths and controllable sizes [5,6]. Vanadate has good energy band structure, low production cost and good photocatalytic performance. Among them, silver vanadium acid (AgVO3) has been known as a possible visible light sensitive semiconductor material due to its narrow band gap and excellent crystallinity. Therefore, it is an ideal material for the preparation of vanadate quantum dots [7â9]. However, quantum dots are very easy to self-aggregate, and surface defects will also affect the stability. Therefore, deposition of quantum dots on multi-dimensional semiconductors is an effective solution [10,11]. Liu et al. modified two-dimensional (2D) carbon nitride (g-C3N4) nanosheets with zero-dimensional (0D) AgVO3 quantum dots. The 0D quantum dots can be uniformly distributed on the 2D g-C3N4 nanometer sheet, promoting the quick transfer of photoelectrons and holes, so as to exert their respective redox effect [12].

In addition, thermal performance is a principal factor affecting photocatalytic performance. It has been reported in some studies that the photothermal effect could facilitate the enhancement of photocatalytic activity [13â15]. The high temperature surface of the photocatalyst can promote the adsorption of pollutants and the desorption of degradation products. Studies have shown that local surface plasmon resonances (LSPRs) of precious metals could enhance the photothermal effect of catalysts [16â18]. However, precious metals are very expensive and not easily available. This makes photocatalysts can be made from cheap and available elements, which is particularly ideal for economic issues in photocatalytic application fields [19,20]. Therefore, some reports about Cu2-xS have attracted much attention. Cu2-xS is a special non-stoichiometric semiconductor plasmon. It has a stoichiometric-dependent band gap (Eg = 1.2â2.1 eV), because copper vacancies can induce collective oscillations of p-type carriers. It exhibits LSPRs effects in the near-infrared region [21â23]. Therefore, it seems to be good candidate to solve the above problems.

It has been reported that photocatalytic efficiency can be improved by combining photocatalysis with other advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) [24,25]. Fenton reaction is one of the most important reactions in AOPs. In recent years, the combination of photocatalysis and Fenton reaction is one of the most common methods to solve environmental problems [26â28]. Constructing a heterojunction photocatalysis-Fenton coupling system can expand the light absorption range, promote the charge separation and transfer, activate the photo-Fenton reaction, and have significant degradation performance. Theoretically, H2O2 can not only react with iron species to generate hydroxyl radicals, but also can quickly capture photogenerated electrons and improve the separation ability of photo-induced carriers. Under the synergistic effect, it can significantly accelerate the oxidation of pollutants. Polyoxometalate (POMs) is a kind of polymetallic oxygen cluster, which can undergo reversible multiple electron transfer [29â31]. Heteropolyacids (HPAs), as a type of POMs, have environmentally friendly characteristics [32]. Among HPAs, heteropoly tungsten acid (HPW) with strong acidity and rich redox chemistry has been widely used in Fenton reaction in recent years [33,34]. Generally, the heterogeneous catalyst in the Fenton reaction process may contain Fe and Mn ions, which can activate H2O2 to generate strong oxidation free radicals [35,36]. Therefore, in Keggin HPW, tungsten can be replaced by low-valent transition metals, [PW11MO39](n-m)-, (M stands for Fe, Mn, etc.), coordinated with the binding sites of heteropolyanions, and can be used as Fenton catalysts. Some studies have proved that heteropolyanions have potential synergistic effects on the Fenton system. However, the complexes formed by iron ions (Fe2+ or Fe3+) and heteropolyanions (PW12O40 3-) are water-soluble, making the catalyst difficult to recycle and reuse [37â40]. Therefore, combining it with a solid support as a heterogeneous catalyst is an important approach to solve the above problems.

Another effective strategy to enhance the photocatalytic performance of semiconductors is to rationally design the shape and structure of the catalyst [41,42]. As a unique morphological structure, the hollow structure has broad prospects in energy and environmental related fields [43â45]. Hollow nanostructures have many advantages: (1) The thin shell topology in the hollow structure shortens the diffusion distance of photo-generated carriers, (2) improves the utilization efficiency of solar radiation through light scattering and reflection effects, (3) accelerate surface reactions by increasing the available specific surface area to separate redox reactions in space [43â45]. Therefore, to optimize the photocatalytic performance, it is worthwhile to conduct in-depth research on the preparation method of hollow nanostructures.

Here, this work combines photothermal and Fenton-like photocatalysis to prepare a hollow cube structure to enhance the performance of photocatalytic degradation. The novel Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 catalyst was prepared on the surface of hollow cube Cu2-xS by a continuous growth deposition method. Through careful design of structure and band gap alignment, Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 composite material has a particular dual Z-scheme heterojunction and hollow cube structure. This hollow structure provides more reactive sites and improves the segregation and mobility of photogenerated carriers. More importantly, Cu2-xS has photothermal effect, which extends the photoresponse to near infrared and effectively improves the photocatalytic activity. In addition, the prepared Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 heterojunction was characterized in detail, and its photocatalytic activity was estimated by photocatalytic-Fenton degradation of bisphenol A, and salicylic acid. In the photocatalytic-Fenton reaction mechanism of Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 dual Z-scheme heterojunction photocatalyst was also proposed.

The synthesis process of the hollow Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 heterogeneous structure is shown in Fig. 1
a.

Preparation of Cu2O nanocubes: In a typical synthesis, CuCl2â2H2O (2 mol Lâ1) was dissolved into 100 mL of deionized water and transfer the solution to a three-necked flask. Then, 10 mL of NaOH solution (2 mol Lâ1) was added to the above solution and stirred for 0.5 h. Then the 10 mL of ascorbic acid solution (0.6 mol Lâ1) was added dropwise to the suspension and stirred for 3 h. All operations were carried out under 55 Â°C water bath condition. The solution was collected by centrifugation, washed with water and ethanol three times each and dry at 50 Â°C for 12 h.

Preparation of Cu2-xS nanocubes: The obtained Cu2O powder was added to 100 mL deionized water and ultrasound was performed for half an hour. Then, 100 mL Na2SÂ·9H2O solution (0.1 mol) was dropped into the above suspension and stirred at 45 Â°C for 1 h. The products were soaked in ammonia solution and stirred. Finally, it was washed three times with deionized water and ethanol, and dried to obtain Cu2-xS powder.

Preparation of Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs: In a typical synthesis, 47 mg of FeCl3 and 22 mg of H3PW12O40âxH2O were dispersed into 80 mL of deionized water and stirred for 1 h. Then, 0.1 g of Cu2-xS was added to the above solution and stirred for 12 h at room temperature. The obtained solution was collected by centrifugation and dried at 50 Â°C for 12 h until the water was completely evaporated. The black powder was denoted as Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs.

Preparation of Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3: The 0.0170 g of AgNO3 powder was added to 20 mL of deionized water and stirred until completely dissolved. Then Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs (0.0243 g) was added to the suspension and stirred, and the resulting solution was sonicated for 1 h. 20 mL of NH4VO3 solution (0.0117 g, 0.1 mmol) via a disposable syringe (20 mL) was added to the suspension at a rate of 60 mL hâ1. The suspension solution was transferred to a round bottom flask and kept in an oil bath at 45 Â°C for 6 h. Finally, the product was collected by centrifugation and placed in an oven at 50 Â°C for 12 h to obtain the black nanocomposite material. The black powder was denoted as Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3. The synthetic procedures for solid Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 were like the preparation of hollow Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3, with solid Cu2-xS used in accordance with a previous report [46].

From the scanning electron microscope (SEM) images, Fig. 1 b-e are Cu2O, Cu2-xS, Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs, and Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 photocatalysts, respectively. Fig. 1 b shows that the Cu2O template has a smooth surface and a cubic structure with sharp edges, with an outer edge width of about 400 nm. In addition, through the transmission electron microscope (TEM) image (Fig. 1 f), it can be observed that the Cu2O template is a solid cube structure. It can be seen from the Fig. 1 c that the surface of the cube Cu2-xS is rougher than that of Cu2O, which can be attributed to the hollow Cu2-xS with Kirkendall effect produced by the surface vulcanization of Cu2O by Na2S solution [47,48]. In the formation process of hollow structure of Cu2-xS, the diffusion speed of copper ions from the inside is faster than the diffusion speed of sulfide ions from the outside (Fig. S1). Subsequently, Cu2O can react with the added ammonia to form a hollow structure of Cu2-xS. Compared with Cu2O, the hollow structure of Cu2-xS can be clearly observed (Fig. S2). As shown in Fig. 1 d, the fold-like cubic surface of Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs nanocomposite may be the result of the formation of Fe-POMs clusters. Fig. 1 e shows that the surface of Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 is rougher, which may be due to the aggregation of AgVO3 nanoparticles on the surface of Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs. In addition, we can observe the formation of many AgVO3 nanoparticles in the TEM image, which is mutually confirmed by SEM (Fig. 1 g).

Compared with the hollow Cu2-xS, the shell thickness of Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 is significantly increased, while the hollow part remains unchanged (Fig. S3). This shows that Fe-POMs and AgVO3 are not deposited inside the hollow structure of Cu2-xS too much, not excluding trace. From the TEM-EDS line scan curve of Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 (Fig. S4), the distribution area of Fe and Ag elements exceeds the position of the Cu2-xS phase, indicating that Fe-POMs and AgVO3 are distributed on the surface of Cu2-xS. This is consistent with the result of the TEM image. In addition, the layered structure of Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 can be visually observed through the element diagram (Fig. 1 jâm). It is found that Cu2-xS has a hollow structure, and Fe-POMs and AgVO3 are mainly deposited on the outer layer of Cu2-xS. The high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image shows that the lattice spacing is 0.20 nm, which corresponds to the (0160) plane of Cu2-xS (Fig. 1 hâi). For AgVO3, obvious monoclinic AgVO3 lattice fringes can be observed on the (-202) plane with a lattice spacing of 0.389 nm. The energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) image shows that the eight elements of Cu, S, Fe, P, W, Ag, V, and O coexist on the entire nanocomposite uniformly (Fig. S5). Consistent with the above results, the formation of nanocomposites is further proved.

As shown in Fig. 2
a, a group of distinct X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) peaks (JCPDS No. 23-0958) of roxbyite Cu7S4 can be detected, which proves the presence of Cu2-xS [48]. For Fe-POMs, due to the low-temperature synthesis process, a weak and broad diffraction peak was found (Fig. S6) [39]. Fe-POMs-related characteristic peaks were not detected in Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 composites, indicating that polyoxometallic acid molecules are highly dispersed on the surface of Cu2-xS. The peaks appearing in the AgVO3 sample may be related to the crystallization of the monoclinic AgVO3 structure with the Cm space group, which is consistent with JCPDS 29-1154 [49], indicating the successful preparation of AgVO3.

Fig. 2 b displays survey X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectrum of Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 composite. The full XPS spectrum of the composite shows that the Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 photocatalyst is composed of eight elements: Cu, S, Fe, P, W, Ag, O, and V indicating the coexistence of Cu2-xS, Fe-POMs, and AgVO3 (Fig. 2 b). Fig. 2 c shows the characteristic peaks for Cu 2p. The peaks at 931.7, 934.0, 951.6, 954.2, and 944.2 eV indicate the presence of 2p3/2 of Cu+, 2p3/2 of Cu2+, 2p1/2 of Cu+, 2p1/2 of Cu2+and the satellite peak of the Cu2+ 2p3/2 oxidation state, respectively [48]. Fig. 2 d shows the S 2p spectrum, which is divided into three evident peaks, attributed to S2â 2p2/3 (161.8 eV), S2â 2p1/2 (163.1 eV), and sulphate species (168.2 eV) Cu-deficient nonstoichiometric sulfides, respectively [22,50]. As for the Ag 3d spectrum (Fig. 2 h), the two peaks at 373.8 and 367.75 eV were caused by Ag 3d3/2 and Ag 3d5/2 in AgVO3, respectively [12,49]. It can be seen from Fig. 2 f that the scan spectrum of V 2p is relatively narrow. The peaks at 524.3 eV and 516.85 eV are represented as the V 2p3/2 state and the V 2p1/2 state, respectively [12,49]. Fig. 2 e shows the high-resolution P 2p spectrum of Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3. The signal at 135.55 and 134.5 eV are allocated to P 2p1/2 and P 2p3/2, respectively [51]. It is easy to observe two asymmetric peaks. The high-resolution W 4f spectrum shows the characteristic spin-orbit coupling dipoles of W 4f5/2 (38.05 eV) and W 4f7/2 (35.95 eV), which proves that the complex has the equal +6 valences of W atoms (Fig. 2 i) [51,52]. For the Fe 2p XPS spectrum (Fig. 2 g), 711.5 and 713.7 eV are both attributed to Fe 2p1/2. The peaks centered at 724.9 eV belong to the Fe 2p3/2 spectra. In addition, the peak at 719.9 eV is the satellite peak of the other four peaks, which proves the existence of Fe3+. This shows that Fe2+ and Fe3+ coexist in the catalyst [39,53]. In the O 1s XPS spectrum (Fig. S7), the peaks at 533.8 and 531.6 eV are attributed to O2 or H2O adsorbed on the catalyst surface, and Cu-O bonds, respectively [48,51]. The peak at 532.85 eV indicates the presence of lattice oxygen combined with phosphorus and tungsten in Fe-POMs [51].

The photothermal effect plays a vital role in improving the photocatalytic activity. The photothermal effect is characterized by the temperature change of the sample surface under the direct heating of the xenon lamp by the infrared thermal drive device. In the photocatalysis process, the main light source is the direct thermal radiation of the light source and the inherent photothermal effect of the sample. As shown in Fig. 3
a, the temperature of the three materials increased after 1 min of irradiation, and the initial temperature was 25 Â°C. For the Cu2-xS, Fe-POMs, and Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 photocatalysts, the temperatures rose to 145, 49, and 120 Â°C, respectively. When combined with Fe-POMs and AgVO3, the optical absorption intensity of Cu2-xS slightly decreases, because dark substances usually have better light absorption properties. Compared with pure Fe-POMs, ternary materials have obvious photothermal effects, which may be due to the LSPR effect of Cu2-xS. Thus, the carefully designed narrow band gap of Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 indeed improves the photothermal effect of the system (Fig. 3 c).

One of the vital factors affecting the activity of the photocatalyst is the photoresponse. As shown in Fig. 3 b, the optical properties of Fe-POMs, Cu2-xS, AgVO3, Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs, and Cu2-xS/Fe-POMS/AgVO3 have been evaluated by ultraviolet-visible diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (UVâvis DRS). It can be seen from Fig. 3 b that the light absorption of Cu2-xS ranges from ultraviolet to infrared. Compared with Fe-POMs and AgVO3, the light absorption range of binary composite materials (Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs) and ternary composite materials (Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3) is significantly extended, from the visible light region to the infrared region. Because dark materials tend to have better light absorption properties [48]. Combined with black Cu2-xS, the light absorption range of the composite material is enhanced. The resultant Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 material responds to different wavelengths of ultraviolet and visible to infrared light, indicating its excellent photothermal effect. This phenomenon may be due to the interaction of the hollow structure of the optical cavity and the plasma nanocrystals. In Fig. S8, the color of Cu2-xS, Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs, and Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 is black, which corresponds to the photoresponse range.

To verify the charge separation and transfer of the prepared samples, a series of tests were carried out. Through steady-state photoluminescence (SS-PL) spectroscopy, the separation of light-induced charges was verified. As clearly demonstrated in Fig. 4
a, Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 showed the lowest SS-PL response among the three prepared materials. It shows that the photo-generated carriers have a low recombination and prolonged lifetime of charge carriers. In addition, the lifetime of photogenerated carriers can also be detected by transient PL. Fig. 4 b shows the transient PL decay curve of the tested substance. The emission decay curve of the sample is fitted by a double exponential kinetic function. The average PL lifetime of each substance is obtained according to the following formula:
(1) Ï = (B1Ï1 2+B2Ï2 2)/(B1Ï1+B2Ï2)

The average PL lifetimes of Cu2-xS, Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs and Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 are 1.08, 2.03, and 2.99 ns, respectively. The results show that Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 has the longest carrier lifetime among all the samples. The significant enhancement in carrier lifetime can effectively increase the availability of light-induced carriers. This can be considered as the formation of the hollow heterojunction system effectively promotes the transfer and separation of carriers, thereby enhancing the carrier lifetime and enhancing the photocatalytic performance.

Through further photoelectrochemical experiments, the movement principle of photogenerated carriers was discussed. In general, the resistance of the interface layer on the electrode surface is represented by the radius of the arc in the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). The results of EIS are shown in Fig. 4 c. The electrochemical impedance of the Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 photocatalyst is much lower than that of other materials, indicating that its charge movement restriction is low. This relaxation can expedite the separation of carriers and improve the progress of the photocatalytic. The transient photocurrent response of the synthesis sample is shown in Fig. 4 d. The magnitude of the transient photocurrent also immediately reflects the charge separation efficiency of the photocatalyst. The photocurrent response intensity of the ternary composite is the highest, indicating that Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 have better photogenerated carrier generation and separation capabilities. This increased photocurrent can be due to the rationally designed band energy alignment layout of the ternary photocatalyst, which improves the transfer and separation of photogenerated carriers. This corresponds to the previous SS-PL results. In addition, the formation of the hollow structure is conducive to the separation and transfer of carriers, thereby improving the photocatalytic performance.

The photocatalytic-Fenton degradation performance of the Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 system for the model pollutant bisphenol A (BPA) under different conditions was evaluated. As shown in Fig. 5
a, the degradation efficiency of the catalyst under the action of light alone or H2O2 alone is negligible. When the Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 system is combined with light or H2O2, the degradation efficiency is significantly improved. The degradation efficiency is up to 98.6 %. This shows that the combination of photocatalysis and heterogeneous Fenton system can expedite the oxidation process of pollutants. The photocatalytic-Fenton degradation performance of the prepared photocatalyst is shown in Fig. 5 b. Within 150 min, the photocatalytic-Fenton degradation efficiency of Cu2-xS, Fe-POMs, AgVO3, Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs and Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 on BPA were 41.8, 24.7, 19.6, 79.4, and 98.6 %, respectively. It can be clearly seen that among all synthetic photocatalysts, Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 has the highest degradation rate of BPA. Compared with other composite materials of literatures, Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 has higher degradation performance for similar pollutants (Table S1). Fig. 5 c shows that the apparent rate constant of Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 is 4.1 Ã 10â2 minâ1, which is approximately 3â13 times faster than that of the Cu2-xS (3.0 Ã 10â3 minâ1), Fe-POMs (1.4 Ã 10â3 minâ1), AgVO3 (1.3 Ã 10â3 minâ1) and Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs (1.2 Ã 10â2 minâ1), respectively. This shows that the degradation efficiency of Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 composite material is better than other comparative samples. Photocatalytic degradation experiments were carried out on a simple mixture of Cu2-xS, Fe-POMs and AgVO3. As shown in Fig. S9, after visible light irradiation for 150 min, the BPA degradation rate of the simply mixed ternary mixture is only 44.3 %. After the formation of heterojunction, the degradation rate of BPA can reach 98.6 %. The experimental results prove that the formation of heterojunction can enhance the photocatalytic-Fenton activity. This may be since the formation of a heterojunction can realize the recycling of Fe. Under the interaction of chemical bonds, the generated electrons can be quickly transferred to Fe3+ to form Fe2+. The reaction between Fe2+ and H2O2 accelerates the efficiency of photoelectron separation, and rapidly generates
OH radicals. In addition, the formation of a heterojunction can promote the charge transfer on the surface of each component, thereby improving the photocatalytic-Fenton activity.

The optimal pH determination experiment shows that under other conditions unchanged, the ternary complex exhibits the best photocatalytic degradation performance at pH = 5 (Fig. 5 e). According to literatures, OH reacts with h+ to produce
OH, which can oxidize pollutants under alkaline or weakly acidic conditions [54]. However, when the pH value is too high, iron hydroxide complexes are formed on the surface of the photocatalyst, resulting in a decrease in the oxidation capacity [39]. It can be seen from Fig. 5 f that as the concentration of H2O2 increases, the degradation efficiency is significantly improved. When the concentration of H2O2 exceeds to 10 mM, the photocatalytic degradation is inhibited. This may be because excessive H2O2 limits the reaction sites and may even lead to active oxygen scavenging [39]. Therefore, under other conditions unchanged, the optimal hydrogen peroxide addition amount is 10 mM. In addition, in the photocatalytic-Fenton catalytic degradation recycling experiment, the stability of the Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 ternary photocatalyst is significant, and the degradation rate only slightly decreases after five cycles and can be ignored (Fig. 5 d). In addition, Fig. S10 shows the XRD patterns of the Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 composite before and after four cycles. This shows that the Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 composite material has almost no obvious phase and structure transformation compared with the fresh one. To further verify the long-term stability of the photocatalyst, 20 cycles of degradation experiments (50 h) were carried out on Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3. It can be seen from Fig. S11 that the photocatalytic degradation rate of Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 is only slightly reduced (91.4 %) after 20 recycles. These results further prove the long-term stability and reusability of Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 heterojunction materials.

To verify that the hollow structure can promote the improvement of photocatalytic activity, we conducted a comparison experiment of photocatalytic degradation on solid and hollow Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 photocatalysts. As shown in Fig. S12, the hollow Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 photocatalyst showed higher photocatalytic degradation activity. This indicates that the hollow structure with abundant active sites and multiple light refraction paths can effectively improve the photocatalytic activity. In addition, to verify that the photothermal effect can improve the photocatalytic effect of the ternary composite material, a photocatalytic degradation experiment of methyl blue by circulating cooling water was carried out (Fig. S13). It can be seen from the figure that after adding circulating cooling water to reduce the catalyst temperature, the degradation rate of Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 for methyl blue is reduced by about 20.9 %. This shows that due to the photothermal effect of Cu2-xS, the ternary composite material also has a photothermal effect. The photocatalyst on the high temperature surface can promote the adsorption of pollutants and the desorption of degradation products, thereby improving the photocatalytic activity.

In addition, as shown in Fig. S14, methyl orange, salicylic acid and methyl blue are selected as simulated pollutants, showing that Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 has excellent photocatalytic degradation performance. Within 150 min, the degradation rates of methyl orange, salicylic acid and methyl blue were up to 89.8, 71.4, and 99.2 %, respectively. As shown in Fig. S15, the photocatalytic-Fenton degradation rate of Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs for BPA is higher than that of Fe-POMs/AgVO3. This indicates that the photothermal effect of Cu2-xS enhances the interaction between the components. The generation rate of hydroxyl radicals is consistent with the separation rate of light-induced charge carriers. In photocatalytic process, it also represents the photocatalytic performance. Since coumarin can easily react with hydroxyl radicals to produce 7-hydroxycoumarin, coumarin is commonly used to determine the content of hydroxyl radicals. It can be seen from Fig. S16, the sequence of obtained fluorescence intensity is as follows: AgVO3 < Fe-POMs < Cu2-xS < Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs < Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3, which is well agreement with the above results. This indicates that the most hydroxyl radicals (
OH) for Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 are produced, which is beneficial to photocatalysis.

The work function was measured by scanning Kelvin probe technology. The contact potential difference between the material and the electrode to determine the work function. As shown in Fig. 6
a, the work function order of each sample is: Cu2-xS > Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs > Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3. It shows that the approximate Fermi level of Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 is higher than the other two samples. This shows that well-designed ternary materials are more conducive to carrier conversion in photocatalytic reactions. To prove the carrier transfer mechanism of the Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 system in the photocatalytic reaction, 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline n-oxide (DMPO) was used as the trapping agent (ESR) Conducted electron spin resonance experiments. Fig. 6 b shows that under dark conditions, no DMPO-
O2 â or DMPO-
OH signal was detected, indicating that the photocatalytic reaction did not occur. After visible light irradiation for 3 min, the response of the DMPO-
OH adduct was obvious. Four peaks with a line intensity of 1:2:2:1 can be accurately observed, confirming the formation of
OH in the photocatalytic reaction. Similarly, for the DMPO-
O2 â adduct, the typical signals of four characteristic peaks with a standard intensity ratio of 1:1:1:1 were detected, which confirmed the generation of
O2 â free radicals in the system. To explore the mechanism of photocatalytic degradation, the main active groups in the reaction process were determined by trapping experiments. The scavengers of
OH, eâ, h+ and
O2â produced in the capture process are isopropanol (IPA), AgNO3, ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA-Na) and p-benzoquinone (BQ). As shown in the Fig. S17, after adding EDTA-Na, AgNO3 and BQ to the system, the degradation rate of MB was significantly reduced, which confirmed the leading role of h+, eâ and
O2â active groups in the photocatalytic reaction. The addition of IPA only slightly reduced the photocatalytic degradation rate, indicating that the
OH active group played a minor role in the reaction. Hence, the order of importance of active groups in this system is: h+ > eâ >
O2 â >
OH.

To further explore the Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 photocatalytic reaction mechanism, the band gap energy (Ebg) and valence band edge positions (EVB) of Cu2-xS, Fe-POMs and AgVO3 were determined. Convert the UVâvis spectrum to the diffuse reflectivity spectrum through the Kubelka-Munk equation [55]:
(2) K = (1-R)2/2R
Here, K indicates the reflectance on the basis of the Kubelka-Munk transformation, and R indicates the reflectivity (%) obtained from the UVâvis spectrum. A Tauc diagram of (ÉhÏ )1/2 vs. hÏ was drawn, and the indirect transition band gap of each component was estimated (Fig. S18). The Ebg of Cu2-xS, Fe-POMs and AgVO3 are 2.0, 3.04, and 2.5 eV, respectively. In addition, the narrow band gap can ease the excitation of electrons and promote the photothermal effect, thereby improving photocatalytic activity. Fig. S19 shows the XPS-VB spectrum, which confirms the band position of each component. On the basis of Mulliken's electronegativity theory, the valence bands (EVB) of Cu2-xS, Fe-POMs and AgVO3 can be obtained as 1.75, 3.45, and 2.24 eV, respectively. The position of the conduction band (ECB) of semiconductor materials can be obtained by the following formula [31]:
(3) ECB = EVB-Ebg
Therefore, the conduction bands of Cu2-xS, Fe-POMs, and AgVO3 are -0.25, 0.41, and -0.26 eV, respectively.

To further study the surface chemical interaction of Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 composite samples, in-situ XPS (under simulated sunlight irradiation) was used to study the changes of the binding energy of each element before and after the composite (Fig. S20). Compared with the original Fe-POMs, after coupling with Cu2-xS and AgVO3, the Fe 2p peak has a positive shift. It shows that the strong interaction between Cu2-xS, Fe-POMs and AgVO3 greatly reduces the electron cloud density of Fe-POMs, and electrons are lost from the surface of Fe-POMs. Compared with the original Cu2-xS and AgVO3, the peaks of Cu 2p and Ag 3d have a negative shift, which indicates that Cu2-xS and AgVO3 get electrons. In addition, to understand the transfer path of the charge, the sample was analyzed by ESR to detect the types of
O2 â and
OH. As shown in Fig. S21, for the original Fe-POMs, only the signal attributed to the DMPO-
OH adduct was detected because the negative ECB value was not enough to reduce O2 to
O2 â. In contrast, for the original Cu2-xS, AgVO3 and Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 only detected signals related to DMPO-
O2 â adducts. Because the positive EVB values of Cu2-xS and AgVO3 are not enough to oxidize H2O/-OH to
OH. However, DMPO-
OH and DMPO-
O2 â signals of binary Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs and ternary Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 were observed at the same time. These results reasonably rule out the possibility of the traditional type II heterojunction in the above-mentioned composite materials. In this case, the photo-generated electrons in Cu2-xS and AgVO3 should be transferred to the CB of Fe-POMs, and the photo-induced holes of Fe-POMs should accumulate on the VB of Cu2-xS and AgVO3. This contradicts the ESR result. Therefore, based on the above analysis, it can be confirmed that the dual Z-scheme charge transfer process is formed in the Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 heterojunction.

Through the above analysis, the possible charge transfer mechanism of Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 photocatalyst was proposed (Fig. 6 c). It can be inferred that in the Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 heterojunction photocatalyst, the charge transfer path generated by light will follow the dual Z-scheme mechanism. The Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 photocatalyst generates electrons and holes under visible light irradiation. First, the photoexcited electrons are transferred from the CB of Fe-POMs to the VB of Cu2-xS and AgVO3. Then, the eâ will recombine with the h+ in the VB of Cu2-xS and AgVO3, respectively. Finally, the photogenerated eâ gather in the CB of Cu2-xS and AgVO3. The electron transferred electrons accumulated in the CB of Cu2-xS and AgVO3 react with O2 to form
O2 â radicals, which participate in the pollutant removal. At the same time, light-induced holes are formed in the VB of Fe-POMs. Hence, the h+ remaining in the VB of Fe-POMs have enough energy to degrade pollutants or oxidize H2O to produce
OH radicals. And
OH can also participate in the removal of organic pollutants. In particular, the new type of hollow structure can produce refraction of light of different wavelengths, which is conducive to light collection. The photocatalytic process may include the following equations:
(4) Cu2-xS/Fe-POM/AgVO3 + hv = eâ+h+
(5) O2 + eâ =
O2 â
(6)
O2 â+ 2H+ = H2O2
(7) h+/
O2 â/
OH + pollutants = H2O + CO2

In addition,
OH can be produced through Fenton reaction or photocatalytic reaction and can synergistically degrade pollutants. The detailed Fenton mechanism is generalized as follows:
(8) Fe2+ + H2O2 = Fe3+ +
OH + OHâ
(9) Fe3+ + H2O2 = Fe2+ +
OOH + H+

In the Fenton reaction, the photoinduced carriers generated by the catalyst promote the reduction of Fe3+ in Fe-POM to Fe2+, and the reaction between Fe3+ and H2O2 generates Â·OOH. H2O2 oxidizes Fe3+ to Fe2+, generating
OH. In this process, Fe2+ and Fe3+ react quickly with Â·OOH, which accelerate the Fe2+/Fe3+ cycle. In addition, the presence of electrons is also conducive to the production of
OH and
O2 â in the Fenton process. They effectively increase the number of active groups and further enhance the photocatalytic activity. The heterojunction superstructure can effectively promote carrier separation, inhibit electron-hole pair recombination, extend the photoresponse range, and thus improve the photocatalytic activity obviously.

In summary, the hollow Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 dual Z-scheme heterojunction was successfully synthesized by the continuous deposition strategy. Under Vis-NIR light, this hollow cubic Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 heterojunction exhibited excellent photocatalytic-Fenton degradation performance for organic pollutants. This optimized photocatalytic activity may be due to the following reasons: (1) the hollow structure provided a large specific surface area, exposed adequate surface active sites, and provided multiple refraction and reflection paths of light, thereby improving the light collection ability of Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3; (2) the synergistic effect of the SPR effect of Cu2-xS, the photocatalysis-Fenton combination, and the formation of dual Z-scheme heterojunctions promoted the migration and separation of photogenerated carriers, thereby improving the photocatalysis-Fenton performance; (3) the prepared dark Cu2-xS/Fe-POMs/AgVO3 photocatalyst had obvious photothermal effect, which improves the utilization rate of light and made it a broad spectrum response, thereby enhancing the photocatalytic performance.
